oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Phenotypic indicators to identify methionine rich European grain legumes and the correlation of grain methionine contents with the sulphur supply
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Paulsen, H. M.
Schumacher, H.
Gau, A. E.
Sass, O.
Jürgens, H.-U.
Dieterich, R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cereals, pulses and oilseeds
Breeding, genetics and propagation
Knowledge management
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Home grown legumes are a valuable protein source for pure on-farm diets for livestock in organic farming. Whereas protein of Glycine max naturally has higher contents of methionine nand also lysine typical European grain legumes (Pisum sativum L., Vicia faba L., Lupinus angustifolius L.) used in organic farms as component of animal food are relatively low in those amino acids.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Paulsen, H. M.; Schumacher, H.; Gau, A. E.; Sass, O.; Jürgens, H.-U. and Dieterich, R. (2010) Phenotypic indicators to identify methionine rich European grain legumes and the correlation of grain methionine contents with the sulphur supply. In: Hera, Christina; Dumitru, Mihail; Schnug, Ewald; Dorneanu, Aurel; Haneklaus, Silvia; Popescu, Ana; Anton, Iulia and Panoiu, Ioana (Eds.) Meeting the fertilizer demand on a changing globe: Biofuels, climate change and contaminats - Proceedings, pp. 90-97.
